metadata.title: Experimental and numerical analysis of rheological characterization of hybrid nano-lubricants containing COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs and oxide nanoparticles

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
International Communications in Heat and Mass Transfer
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ichmt
Experimental and numerical analysis of rheological characterization of hybrid nano-lubricants containing COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs and oxide nanoparticles Ahmadreza Ghaffarkhaha, Amin Bazzia, Zahra Azimi Dijvejinb, Mohsen Talebkeikhaha, Mostafa Keshavarz Moravejic,⁎, Farough Agina a Department of Petroleum Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology (Tehran Polytechnic), 424 Hafez Avenue, Tehran 15875-4413, Iran bDepartment of Petroleum Engineering, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran 14115114, Iran c Department of Chemical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology (Tehran Polytechnic), 424 Hafez Avenue, Tehran 15875-4413, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Hybrid nano-lubricant COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs Decision tree Random forest
A B S T R A C T
In this study, the dynamic viscosity of four different hybrid nano-lubricants was investigated. The base fluid was SAE 40 engine oil. The suspended nanoparticles consisted of 20 Vol% of COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs and 80 Vol% of oxide nanoparticles (SiO2, Al2O3, MgO, and ZnO). The experiments were performed at temperatures between 25 and 50°∁ and solid volume fractions of 0.05, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75 and 1%. In addition, the decision tree, random forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Radial Basis Function Artificial Neural Networks (RBF-ANN) were used to predict the viscosity of prepared nanofluids. The decision tree and random forest methods have the highest accuracy in terms of predicting the dynamic viscosity of prepared nano-lubricants.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Developing the heat transfer fluids with an enhanced thermal conductivity is an important issue in a broad range of industrial fields such as oil and gas, automotive and electrical or nuclear energies [1–4]. Conventional heat transfer fluids such as oil, water and ethylene glycol (EG) have low thermal conductivity [5,6]. Adding thermal conductive nanoparticles to conventional heat transfer fluids could effectively improve their heat transfer capacities [7,8]. This in turn resulted into the increasing the life-cycle of working fluids, reducing the size of equipment and enhancing the efficiency of the application [9].
So far, a number of studies have investigated the effect of adding nanoparticles on thermal conductivity of traditional heat transfer fluids [10–14]. Choi et al. [15] added Al2O3 and AlN nanoparticles to transformer oil and observed about 20% enhancement in its overall heat transfer coefficient. Zyła [16] experimentally investigated the effect of MgO nanoparticles on thermo-physical properties of EG and reported that thermal conductivity has increased up to 33% by adding 7.2 vol% of nanoparticles. Agarwal et al. [17] evaluated the thermal conductivity of Al2O3 nanofluids in different base fluids. The results of this study showed that ethylene glycol based Al2O3 nanofluids show higher thermal conductivity compared to distilled water Al2O3 nanofluids.
Other thermo-physical properties of heat transfer fluids such as density, electrical conductivity and viscosity are also affected by dispersing nanoparticles in them. The viscosity of nanofluids is considered as the second most important parameter since it directly affects the pressure drop of the system [18–20]. A literature review of the available studies on thermo-physical properties of different types of nanofluids is presented in Table 1.
Carbon nanoparticle, such as nanotube, carbon nanofibers, diamond and grapheme are known to have the highest increase in thermal conductivity of conventional heat transfer fluids [32–36]. Generally, a very high amount of oxide or metal nanoparticles should be dispersed in a fluid to increase its thermal conductivity to the level of a more dilute solution of carbon nanoparticles [37–39]. Using high amount of nanoparticles reduces the stability, increases costs, reduce the fluidity of heat transfer fluids and greatly affects the viscosity of nanofluids [40–42]. In recent years, growing attention has been made to carbon based hybrid nanofluids which are consisted of carbon nanoparticles and other types of nanoparticles (i.e. chemically stable metals, metal oxides and oxide ceramic nanoparticles) [43–46]. Hybrid carbon based nanofluids have a desirable heat transfer and pressure drop characteristics [47–50]. A literature review on the available studies of hybrid carbon based nanofluids is presented in Table 2.
Several researchers have used different numerical methods such as
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.icheatmasstransfer.2019.01.003
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: moraveji@aut.ac.ir (M. Keshavarz Moraveji).
International Communications in Heat and Mass Transfer 101 (2019) 103–115
0735-1933/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
genetic algorithms, Artificial Neural Network (ANN) and Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) in order to process thermophysical properties of nanofluids and obtain valid conclusions about the performance of different types of nanofluids in various operational conditions [60–64]. Ariana et al. [65] used ANN approach to estimate the thermal conductivity of alumina water-based nanofluids. Esfahani et al. [5] exercised ANFIS to determine viscosity and thermal conductivity of silver, copper and titanium oxide nanoparticles dispersed in mineral insulating oil. Rostamian et al. [66] employed the Multilayer Perception of Neural Network (MLP-ANN) to predict thermal conductivity of CuO-SWCNTs-EG water (40:60) nanofluids. Alade et al. [67] determined the thermal conductivity enhancement of metal and metallic oxide nanofluids using SVM.
Based on the above mentioned works, it can be concluded that many researchers have evaluated and compared the effect of various nanoparticles on thermo-physical properties of different base fluids. Nevertheless, only a few comprehensive experimental and numerical studies have been performed on viscosity of engine oil nanofluids. However, the viscosity of oil based nanofluids is one of the key factors of saving energy and improving the durability of heat engines [55,68].
In this study, regarding the importance of the viscosity of oil based nanofluids, several hybrid nanfluids (COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs/ SiO2, COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs/ZnO, COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs/MgO, and COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs/Al2O3) have been prepared with SAE 40 engine oil. Then, the effects of nanoparticle concentration and temperature on viscosity of hybrid oil based nanofluids are evaluated. Furthermore, several numerical methods (i.e. decision tree, random forest, SVM and RBF-ANN) have been used to
predict the viscosity of prepared nanofluids. For modeling, viscosity was considered as the target data and the volume fraction and temperature were regarded as the input data. To the best of authors' knowledge, the decision tree and random forest methods have not been used by other researchers to predict the various properties of nanofluids.

sections.heading: 2.1. Material description
sections.text: In this research, Al2O3 (US-Nano Co., USA), MgO (Sigma-Aldrich, USA), ZnO (US-Nano Co., USA), SiO2 (US-Nano Co., USA), and COOHFunctionalized MWCNT (US-Nano Co., USA) were used. In order to confirm the nanoparticles sizes and morphological characterizations, Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM), Scanning electron microscope (SEM) or Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) pictures of these nanoparticles are presented in Fig. 1. The specifications of used nanoparticles are summarized in Table 3. SAE 40 engine oil was purchased from IRANOL Oil Co, Iran. The characteristics of SAE 40 engine oil are presented in Table 4.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nanofluid preparation
sections.text:
Different hybrid nanofluids were produced by the two step method. First, nanoparticles were dispersed into SAE 40 oil using high speed homogenizer (T25 digital ULTRA-TURRAX, IKA, China) for about two hours. Then, in order to prevent nanoparticles agglomeration, the
suspensions were sonicated using ultrasonic processor (UP 200 St, Hielscher, Japan) for four hours. As can be seen in Fig. 2, no obvious sedimentation was observed in nanofluids containing 1 Vol% nanoparticles after 10 days.
The suspended nanoparticles consisted of 20 Vol% of COOHFunctionalized MWCNTs and 80 Vol% of oxide nanoparticles (i.e. SiO2, Al2O3, MgO, and ZnO). Stable nanofluids with different solid volume fractions of 0.05, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75 and 1% were prepared. It should be noted that in higher solid volume fractions, an agglomeration of nanoparticles occurs and long term stability significantly reduces. The
required weight of different nanoparticles for achieving a desired volume concentration can be calculated based on the following equation [56]:

sections.heading: 2.3. Viscosity measurement
sections.text:
Viscometer CAP 2000+ (Brookfield Engineering Laboratories, USA) was used to measure the viscosity of nanofluids at temperatures between 25 and 50°∁. The accuracy of this viscometer is equal to± 2%. While, the repeatability of this viscometer was measured to be around±0.5%. In this study, CAP-1 spindle on high torque was used for all measurements.

sections.heading: 3.1. ANN
sections.text:
ANNs have been used in solving a variety of problems in recognition of pattern, prediction, optimization, and control [69]. ANNs are known as tools for computational modeling of complex and nonlinear problems [70]. ANNs are comprised of interconnected adaptive elements which are called nodes or artificial neurons. These neurons are able to perform extensively parallel computations for processing of data [71,72]. The mechanism of ANNs is inspired from the human brain, which are capable of learning and generalizing from the experience [73]. Artificial neuron receives inputs from the environment, passes them through a linear threshold gate, and sends the signal (output) to another neuron. The perceptron allows the passing when the net input is stronger than the limit of threshold (bias). This process leads to activation of neuron fire. For n signals, the operation of perceptron neuron is as follows [70]:
= <
y w x b
w x b

n i i

n i i
1
1 (2)
1 indicates “on” and 0 indicates “off” in the system. ANNs are classified in various ways, according to their features. This classification is based on the function of ANN which is designed to operate (such as clustering), the degree of the connectivity of neurons, the flow direction of information through the network which are recurrent and non-recurrent, type of learning algorithm, the learning rule, and required learning supervision of training the ANN [70]. Two types of ANNs are utilized in this paper. These two types are RBF-ANN and SVM.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. RBF-ANN
sections.text:
RBF-ANN consisting three layers are a feed-forward error-back propagation network [72]. These three layers are input, hidden, and output layers. They are trained by different learning algorithms such as two-step hybrid learning [74]. The nodes in the hidden layer are cluster centers. The inputs of the first layer are clustered in the hidden layer. RBF-ANNs utilize functions such as Gaussian kernel. In such networks, center location and deviation are the main characteristics. The RBFANN can be defined as below [74,75]:
= = … = … = f x w x c i N k M( ) (|| ||) 1, , 1, ,i i N i ki k i1
(3)
First, the distance between vector of inputs (xk) and center location is calculated. Then, the calculated distances are mapped to the kernel function (φki) in cluster i (M is the number of inputs and N is the number of clusters). Meanwhile, kernel functions which are nonlinear units of RBF-ANNs along with weight parameter(wi), create a linear connection between hidden layer and output layer [74,75].

sections.heading: 3.1.2. SVM
sections.text: SVM is a technique used for pattern recognition, regression, solving linear operator equations and nonlinear classification. Unlike other types of neural networks, the SVM does not contain the limitation of over-fitting and under-fitting [76,77]. In this method, input data are mapped to a higher space dimension called kernel function. Therefore, classifying data in two classes is easily achievable since the mapped data are linearly separable. SVM maximizes the margin between classified classes by finding the optimal hyperplane. This can be conducted by using Quadratic Programming (QP) optimization method [76–78].

sections.heading: 3.2. Decision tree
sections.text: Classification and Regression tree (CART) technique is a supervised learning tool used for cause-and-effect analyses. CART is classified into the decision or classification tree and regression tree [79]. These two types are selected according to the type of variables. If the variables are categorical, the decision tree is used. Otherwise, if the variables are continuous and discrete, the regression tree is used [80]. The objective of the decision tree is to predict the outcome of the set of variables as inputs by finding the set of rules [81]. Decision trees are attractive in data mining for several reasons. First, they are easily pervasive because of their intuitive representation. The second reason is that decision trees do not need any parameter setting from the user and hence are applicable in knowledge discovery. Third, decision trees are relatively fast in comparison to other methods. The last reason is the accuracy of decision trees among other classification methods [82]. Both methods follow the same protocol. During the decision tree procedure, parent nodes (first conditions) split into two child nodes. The splitting continues until no further splitting occurs (terminal nodes). This process is called binary recursive partitioning. The splitting is carried out based on the effect of inputs on the output by which the square error between real and predicted data is minimized. Once the decision tree is completed, a logical sequence of splitting criteria can be obtained [83].

sections.heading: 3.3. Random forests
sections.text:
Random forests were first introduced by Bierman for classification and regression problems [84]. Beirman showed that for increasing the accuracy of classification and regression, ensembles of the trees are needed. In other word, random forests are ensembles of various unpruned decision trees [84]. In ensemble classification, not only one but several classifiers are trained and their results are combined together by voting process. The most known methods are boosting and bagging [84,85]. Random forests use resembling but improved method of bootstrapping as bagging. Random forests have shown their comparability to boosting in term of accuracy regardless to the drawbacks of boosting [84,86]. Random forests method is easy to implement, offer
accurate predictions and is suitable for large set of input variables without over fitting. In this technique, a group of samples is randomly selected and the remaining are used to test each tree. In fact, at each node, each tree is formed at random and by selecting the best split and then a small group of inputs or features split into sub nodes. This is repeated for all trees to increase the diversity of trees and reinforce the prediction accuracy. The tree is grown by utilizing CART methodology in order to reach the maximum size and no pruning. Different parameters are used by random forests to grow the trees [87,88]. These parameters include number of trees, subset size, and number of nodes. Number of trees and size of the subset are optimized to calculate the least error in ensembles of trees [84,89].

sections.heading: 4.1. Rheological behavior
sections.text:
The dynamic viscosity of nanofluids directly affects their pumping power, heat and mass transfer behavior. In terms of rheological behaviors, fluids can be classified into two groups of Newtonian and nonNewtonian fluids. While the viscosity of non-Newtonian fluids changes due to variable shear rate, Newtonian fluids tend to exhibit constant viscosity at all shear rates. The dynamic viscosity of SEA 40 engine oil and prepared hybrid nanofluids, containing 1 Vol% nanoparticles, at various RPMs is shown in Fig. 3. It is seen in Fig. 3 that the base oil and prepared nano-lubricants exhibit Newtonian behavior since their viscosity is constant at various RPMs.
4.2. Effects of temperature and solid volume fraction on viscosity of nanofluids
The dynamic viscosity of prepared hybrid nanofluids versus solid volume fraction is shown in Fig. 4. As can be seen, the dynamic viscosity of hybrid nanofluids slowly increases by increasing the volume fraction of nanoparticles. It is observed that in lower temperatures, the viscosity enhancement is more obvious compared to those at higher temperature. It should be noted that adding nanoparticles and nanotubes in engine oil causes an interaction between nanoparticles and oil molecules which in turn resulted into the increasing the viscosity of fluid. In higher temperatures, this interaction reduces. As a result, the value of viscosity enhancement is higher at lower temperatures [51,90]. Comparing the results presented in Fig. 4 also shows that the type of
oxide nanoparticles has an insignificant effect on dynamic viscosity of nanofluids. The samples containing 20 Vol% of COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs and 80 Vol% of oxide nanoparticles have an almost similar dynamic viscosity at a same temperature and solid volume fraction.
The dynamic viscosity versus temperature for prepared hybrid nanofluids is shown in Fig. 5. For all cases, the dynamic viscosity of samples reduces by increasing the temperature with a similar trend. It is observed that the reduction of viscosity by increasing the temperature is larger for samples with higher solid volume fractions. This is mainly because the interaction between nanoparticles and oil molecules are more likely to be affected by temperature in higher concentrations of nanoparticles [55].

sections.heading: 4.3. Comparison between experimental outcomes and available theoretical correlations
sections.text:
The Batchelor [91] (Eq. (4)), Wang [92] (Eq. (5)), and Esfe [58] (Eq. (6)) models were used to predict the dynamic viscosity of nanofluids.
= + + µ µ (1 2.5 6.2 )nf bf 2
(4)
= + + µ µ (1 7.23 123 )nf bf 2
(5)
= + + + µ µ a a a a( )nf bf 0 1 2 2 3 3
(6)
where, μnf is the dynamic viscosity of the nanofluid in m Pa.s, μbf is the dynamic viscosity of the base fluid in m Pa.s,
µ µ nf bf is the viscosity ratio,
and a0, a1, a2, and a3 are the constant values, which are mentioned in [58].
A comparison between measured viscosity ratio (for samples containing 1 Vol% nanoparticles) and predicted outcomes of the above mentioned models is shown in Fig. 6. As can be seen, these theoretical models could not effectively predict the rheological behavior of prepared hybrid nanofluids. It is worth to mention that the Esfe model [58] was obtained based on the experimental data of the MWCNTs/SiO2 (20–80) SAE 40 hybrid nano-lubricants. The only difference between our work and the study which was performed by Esfe et al. [58] was the usage of COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs instead of MWCNTs. However, the Esfe et al. [58] model was also unable to predict the viscosity
of prepared hybrid nanofluids. This demonstrates the existence of a need for more robust methods for predicting the rheological behavior of hybrid nanofluids.

sections.heading: 4.4. Numerical modeling
sections.text:
In this section the predicting performance of the implemented models is evaluated. A summary of the implemented models and their input and output parameters is shown in Fig. 7. In almost all of the previous studies in the field of predicting the dynamic viscosity of nanofluids using soft-computing approach, the input data of numerical models belonged to a single type of nanofluids. However, in this study, the input data of the implemented numerical models belongs to four types of nanoparticle systems (COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs/SiO2, COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs/ZnO, COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs/ MgO, and COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs/Al2O3). As a result, the outcomes of the implemented models of this study are not limited to a
single type of nanoparticles and can be used to describe the rheological behavior of hybrid nanofluids containing 20 Vol% of COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs and 80 Vol% of oxide nanoparticles.
Fig. 8 shows a comparison between experimental data and results of various implemented models. As can be seen, the difference between experimental data and model prediction is much lower in decision tree and SVM compared to random forest and RBF-ANN methods. In Fig. 9, regression plots for different models are presented. In this figure, the vertical and horizontal axes are experimental and predicted values. This figure again shows the higher accuracy of decision tree and SVM
compares to random forest and RBF-ANN methods. The amount of error for different implemented models is shown in Fig. 10. It is clear that the smallest deviation belongs to decision tree and SVM methods, while the RBF-ANN has the lowest accuracy in terms of predicting the dynamic viscosity of hybrid nanofluids. As it has been mentioned before, in this study, decision tree and random forest methods were used for the first time to predict the dynamic viscosity of nanofluids. The results presented in Figs. 8 to 10 show decision tree method can be used in future studies to predict various properties of nanofluids.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
The dynamic viscosity of four different hybrid nano-lubricant containing COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs and oxide nanoparticles was experimentally investigated. In addition, the decision tree, random forest, SVM, and RBF-ANN were used to predict the viscosity of prepared nanofluids. The summary of the results acquired by this study is mentioned below:
1. For all samples, by increasing the temperature the dynamic viscosity of prepared hybrid nano-lubricants reduces. 2. For all samples, by increasing the solid volume fraction the dynamic viscosity of prepared hybrid nano-lubricants increases. 3. The type of oxide nanoparticles has an insignificant effect on the dynamic viscosity of prepared hybrid nano-lubricants. 4. Available theoretical models in the literature could not effectively predict the dynamic viscosity of prepared hybrid nano-lubricants. 5. The decision tree and SVM methods have a higher accuracy in terms of predicting the dynamic viscosity of prepared hybrid nano-lubricants. 6. In this study, for the first time, the decision tree and random forest methods were used to predict the dynamic viscosity of hybrid
nanofluids. Nevertheless, only the decision tree method is recommended for future studies in the field of predicting the nanofluid properties due to its high accuracy.

metadata.abstractText: In this study, the dynamic viscosity of four different hybrid nano-lubricants was investigated. The base fluid was SAE 40 engine oil. The suspended nanoparticles consisted of 20 Vol% of COOH-Functionalized MWCNTs and 80 Vol% of oxide nanoparticles (SiO2, Al2O3, MgO, and ZnO). The experiments were performed at temperatures between 25 and 50°∁ and solid volume fractions of 0.05, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75 and 1%. In addition, the decision tree, random forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Radial Basis Function Artificial Neural Networks (RBF-ANN) were used to predict the viscosity of prepared nanofluids. The decision tree and random forest methods have the highest accuracy in terms of predicting the dynamic viscosity of prepared nano-lubricants.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
